thread.title: Windjammers, Panthers, islanders make their pitch in weekend play
thread.title_full: Windjammers, Panthers, islanders make their pitch in weekend play

author: news@courierpublicationsllc.com (Staff)
title: Windjammers, Panthers, islanders make their pitch in weekend play
text:
High school boys and girls soccer Windjammers, Panthers, islanders make their pitch in weekend play Girls squads cement wins, boys teams falter as season's end approaches By Staff | Oct 05, 2015 
Midcoast high school soccer squads were in action for Classes A, B and D in recent days, a scenario that proved good news for the girls — while not as positive for the boys. 
The Camden Hills squads split with Class A Lewiston as the girls earned a 5-0 win in Rockport, while the boys fell 3-1 to the Blue Devils in Lewiston in games played on Friday, Oct. 2. 
The Vinalhaven-North Haven teams also played Buckfield in a pair of games Friday and Saturday, Oct. 2-3, as the island girls earned a split on the weekend and the boys dropped both games to the Bucks. 
The Medomak Valley girls also traveled to face Maranacook of Readfield and earned a 2-0 win on Saturday, Oct. 3, which snapped the Panthers' six-game losing streak. 
The following is a recap of reported results: 
Girls soccer 
Camden Hills 5, Lewiston 0 
At Rockport Oct. 2, the Windjammers remained unbeaten as they prevailed over the Blue Devils. 
Leading the Windjammer offense were Charlotte Messer (3 goals), Emma Gutheinz (goal, assist), Emily Blackwell (goal) and Eliza Roy (assist). 
Camden Hills held a 19-1 lead in shots. Jana Speiker played in goal for the Windjammers, while Kelsey St. Cyr made 13 saves for the Blue Devils. 
In the Maine Principals' Association Heal Point Standings for Class A North, Camden Hills (9-0-1, 86.4286 points) is first in the 14-team region. The top 10 teams qualify for the playoffs. 
Medomak Valley 2, Maranacook 0 
At Readfield Oct. 3, the Panthers' six-game losing streak came to a close as they bested the host Black Bears. 
Talia Willis and Abby Nelson creased the net for Medomak Valley, off assists by Maggie Cox and Aubrey Schaeffer. Chelsea Ripley earned the shutout in goal for the visitors. 
Coach Larry Jensen said his team has “been playing well just [getting] unlucky breaks” and “played 80 minutes of soccer” in Saturday's win. 
He said Sophie Cohen, Hannah Watmough, Emily Wotton and Gabby DePatsy “played very well” defensively against Marancook. 
In the Maine Principals' Association Heal Point Standings for Class B North, Medomak Valley (2-8, 7.7551 points) is 16th, while Oceanside of Rockland/Thomaston (8-0-1, 73.6735 points) is first in the 18-team region. The top 12 teams qualify for the playoffs. 
Boys soccer 
Lewiston 3, Camden Hills 1 
At Lewiston Oct. 2, the Windjammers now are in the midst of a rare two-game losing streak as they fell to the unbeaten Blue Devils. Lewiston led 1-0 at halftime. 
Noralddin Othman scored two goals for Lewiston and Abdi Sharriff-Hassan one, while Kienan Brown scored a second-half goal for Camden Hills. 
The Blue Devils held a 26-8 edge in shots and a 4-1 advantage in corner kicks. Lucas Boetsch made 18 saves in net for Camden Hills, while Austin Wing made two saves in goal for Lewiston. 
The Windjammers' chances took a shot in the first half when Josh Pitcairn was sent to the hospital after having his head cut open by a Blue Devils player. Camden Hills coach Ryan Hurley said it was due to a Lewiston player participating in the game without a mouth guard and the player's teeth “took a chunk” out of Pitcairn's head. 
Hurley said Pitcairn had four staples put in his head to close the cut (staples are used now instead of stitches) following the incident. 
“That was really unfortunate, but the rest of the boys rallied and the substitutes played great,” the coach said. “Lewiston's first goal was a great goal where they capitalized on some early game jitters on our part. Their second goal really should have been a foul and a free kick for us as Lucas came out and made a sliding save and one of the Lewiston forwards kicked him in the face as he was on the ground, [and] the ball popped over to another player who tucked it in. Kienan Brown scored a really nice goal and we had a few more good opportunities off set pieces at the end. It was a really fun game with a playoff-type atmosphere. Hopefully we'll get the opportunity to play them again." 
In the Maine Principals' Association Heal Point Standings for Class A North, Camden Hills (6-2-2, 61.9388 points) is third, while Lewiston (10-0, 92.5510 points) is first in the 14-team region. The top 10 teams qualify for the playoffs. 
Courier Publications' sports staff can be reached by email at sports@villagesoup.com or by phone at 594-4401.
